articles.title: About this Workshop
articles.description:
The purpose of this workshop is to introduce the [DemocratizingData.ai](https://democratizingdata.ai/tools/dashboards/) platform and the uses of its dashboard to research-oriented agricultural economists. The DemocratizingData.ai platform has been developed to track data usage statistics for USDA data assets. The goal of the workshop is to gather feedback from invited participants about the current functionality of the USDA dashboard and potential future improvements. The format of the workshop is guided focus groups and interactive discussions designed for attendees to contribute to shaping the ongoing developments of the tool.

The workshop is led by agricultural economists Drs. [Allie Bauman](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=KsJSnW4AAAAJ&hl=en&oi=ao), [Alessandro Bonanno](https://agsci.colostate.edu/old-dare/people/faculty/dr-alessandro-bonanno/), [Lauren Chenarides](https://www.linkedin.com/in/laurenchenarides/), and [Rebecca Cleary](https://agsci.colostate.edu/old-dare/people/faculty/dr-rebecca-cleary/) from Colorado State University. The workshop facilitator is Dr. [Mayla Boguslav](https://www.linkedin.com/in/mayla-boguslav-phd-30402239/).

The workshop is supported by funding from the USDA Economic Research Service.

articles.title: Dashboard Demo and Breakout Group Activities
articles.contents:
Contents
What to Expect
Introductions
Activity #1
Thought Experiment
Questions
Quick Poll

Activity #2
Dashboard Walkthrough
On Your Own
Reflection Questions


As a reminder, we kindly ask that you follow these Zoom etiquette guidelines.
Keep video on.
Use the “Raise Hand” feature.
Be on mute unless you’re speaking.
Respect comments.
Ask for clarification in the chat.
What to Expect
We will remain in the breakout groups for the next 50 minutes. The structure of the breakout room is as follows:
Activity
Time Allotted
Introductions
5 minutes
Activity #1
15 minutes
Activity #2
22 minutes
Reflection Questions
8 minutes
Introductions
Total Time: 5 minutes
Welcome, everyone! Let’s start off with a quick icebreaker.
Please introduce yourself by sharing:
Your name.
The institution or organization you’re affiliated with.
Think of a paper you’re currently working on. Share the dataset you’re using and how you’re accessing it.
Activity #1
Total Time: 15 minutes
In today’s rapidly evolving research landscape, the ability to quickly and effectively find relevant datasets can be the difference between publishing in a top field journal or spending months finding the right publication home; securing funding for that highly competitive research grant or not; and spending hours instead of days searching for the right dataset for your research project.
We recognize the challenges associated with sorting through vast amounts of available datasets. Initiatives, like the one being featured today (DemocratizingData.ai), are being developed to simplify components of this process. These efforts require contributions from the community, which is why we have convened this workshop.
This first activity aims to explore these opportunities by conceptualizing an ideal tool for tracking dataset usage statistics. Understanding these statistics informs the public about the relevance and impact of various datasets, and provides information to researchers about the most widely-used (and under-utilized) resources for their work.
Thought Experiment
To conceptualize this ideal tool, we will go through a role-playing scenario.
Scenario: Assume you have become aware of a new (to you) dataset and you want to understand whether it is useful for your research and how others have used it.
Objective: We will walk through a series of questions to understand your decision-making process in determining the usefulness of this dataset to you.
Instructions: For answering the questions, we’ll use Idea Boards, an online collaboration tool that allows participants to share their thoughts and insights through sticky notes.
Short tutorial on how to use an Idea Board.
When instructed, please navigate to your group’s Idea Board:
Breakout Group
Discussant
Link to Idea Board
Group 1
Allie Bauman
Idea Board 1
Group 2
Rebecca Cleary
Idea Board 2
Group 3
Alessandro Bonanno
Idea Board 3
Group 4
Lauren Chenarides
Idea Board 4
A short guide on how to use Idea Boards:
Navigate to the provided link to access our group’s Idea Board.
Once there, you’ll find different columns, each corresponding to a specific question or part of our discussion.
To add your input, click on the ‘Add Sticky’ button (the green plus sign) in the column where you want to post your sticky note.
You will see a new sticky note appear - start typing your comment.
Feel free to move your notes around, edit them as the discussion evolves, or “up vote” sticky notes written by others in your group.
Questions
Scenario: Assume you have become aware of a new (to you) dataset and you want to understand whether it is useful for your research and how others have used it.
What key pieces of information would you want to know about the usage of this dataset?
Add your responses as sticky notes to the “Pieces of Information” Idea Board.
Time: 3 minutes

Are there tools / resources that can provide you with the information you want?
Add your responses as sticky notes to the “Tools / Resources” Idea Board.
Time: 3 minutes

What features does, or should, a tool / resource have to help you decide if the dataset is useful?
Add your responses as sticky notes to the “Features” Idea Board.
Time: 3 minutes

Quick Poll

Loading…

Link to poll
Activity #2
Total Time: 30 minutes
For the next activity, we will walk you through a prototype dashboard that provides data usage information about USDA datasets. (Access the dashboard here.)
The primary functions of the dashboard include:
Identifying users of USDA-produced datasets by region, institution, and field
Providing information on publications and citations featuring USDA-produced datasets
Dashboard Walkthrough
Time: 7 minutes
Let’s walk through the dashboard using an example dataset: Farm to School Census. This will help everyone familiarize themselves with the dashboard and the types of questions we will be exploring. Please note that there are many features of this dashboard, so the purpose of this tutorial is to give you a framework of how to use the tool. You will have the opportunity to explore this dashboard in greater depth on your own.


The guide above walks through the current version of the Democratizing Data dashboard.
Questions
Task
Task Description
Answer
1
Locate your dataset: Navigate to where you can filter USDA-produced datasets.
Select “Farm to School Census” for this tutorial
2
Identify an expert: Who can we ask for help?
Becca Jablonski
3
Identify five papers: What papers can we read that have used this dataset?
Big Hunger
4
Explore publications by citation count: What journal has the most publications using this dataset?
Journal of Hunger and Environmental Nutrition
5
Explore publications by specific sub-field: What journals in Ag Econ have published manuscripts using this dataset?
Go to “All Science Journal Classification Subfields”, select “Economics and Econometrics”
Democratizing Data User Guide


The guide above provides additional information developed by the Democratizing Data team. Link to guide
On Your Own
Time: 15 minutes
Overview: Now you will explore the utility and functionality of the prototype dashboard on your own. This activity is designed to highlight different aspects of the dashboard and how you can use it to collect data usage statistics.
Objective: To assess the relevance and usefulness of the statistics provided by the prototype dashboard, and to evaluate how effectively the dashboard meets the needs of a research-oriented user community, focusing specifically on the statistics collected and displayed.
Group Assignments: Each group will focus on a different dataset. Answer the same set of questions as we have practiced with the Farm to School Census. Please navigate the dashboard on your own. The datasets for each group are as follows:
Breakout Group
Discussant
Assigned Dataset
Group 1
Allie Bauman
Census of Agriculture
Group 2
Rebecca Cleary
FoodAPS
Group 3
Alessandro Bonanno
Current Population Survey – Food Security Supplement
Group 4
Lauren Chenarides
Food Access Research Atlas

>>>Link to Dashboard<<<


Questions
Respond to the series of questions to uncover detailed data usage statistics. After completing the tasks, we will regroup to share insights and discuss your experiences.
As you navigate the dashboard to answer the questions, please make use of the chat feature in Zoom to provide comments, in real time, about your experience. Our note takers will be collecting your feedback.
Locate your assigned dataset: Navigate to the location on the page where you can filter USDA-produced datasets.
Prompt: As you filter through the datasets, please describe the ease or difficulty you encounter in locating your assigned dataset. Are the filtering options intuitive? Share any suggestions via the Zoom chat.
Identify an expert: Who can we ask for help?
Prompt: When identifying an expert to consult about the dataset, please note how accessible this information is on the dashboard. Is the contact information sufficiently detailed? Do you know someone who has used this dataset? Can you find this person in the list? How could this feature be enhanced to better support your research needs?
Identify five papers: What papers can we read that have used this dataset?
Prompt: As you search for papers that have used this dataset, comment on the search functionality. Is the information easy to find? Are the search results well-organized and relevant? Please provide specific examples of any challenges you face.
Explore publications by citation count: What journal has the most publications featuring this dataset? What journal has the most citations featuring this dataset?
Prompt: As you examine the journals ranked by publication or citation count, please evaluate how this information helps you assess the impact of the dataset. Are these metrics clear and useful? Suggest how this feature could be more informative.
Explore publications by specific sub-field: What other journals, related to Agricultural Economics, have published manuscripts using this dataset?
Prompt: Review the journals related to Agricultural Economics using the “Classification and Research Areas” sub-fields. Do you find the segmentation by sub-field helpful? Please discuss any gaps or additional sub-fields that should be included to refine this tool.
Explore classifications and research areas: From the dropdown list in the “Classification and Research Areas” section of the dashboard, which classification schema do you find most relevant to your work?
Prompt: Reflect on the relevance of the current classification schema to your work. Are there terms or classifications missing that could enhance the dashboard’s utility? Suggest any other terms or classifications that you believe would better represent or describe the research disciplines related to this dataset.
Explore additional dashboard components: Investigate other features and statistics available on the dashboard that have not been covered in the previous questions.
Prompt: As you explore other components of the dashboard, please comment on any statistics or features you find particularly insightful, or features that would improve the utility of the dashboard. How do these components contribute to your understanding of the dataset’s usage? Please provide feedback on any additional insights you discover during your exploration. Share how these elements could enhance your understanding or usage of the dataset.
Reflection Questions
Time: 8 minutes
After you have gone through the dashboard and answered the questions, let’s review the following questions as a group. Note takers, please document the responses to share with the larger group.
What features of the dashboard did you find particularly useful or surprising?
What limitations or problems did you encounter while navigating the dashboard?
What features would you add to the dashboard?
Is there anything else that you would like to share about your experience using the dashboard?
Thank you for sharing. We will now reconvene with the rest of the participants to share your reflections from these activities.






Go to Large Group Share

Thank You from Spiro Stefanou

            About this Workshop
            Why Are We Here? To introduce the DemocratizingData.ai platform, its
            dashboard, and its uses to researchers in agricultural
            economics.
            What Is It? The DemocratizingData.ai
            platform aims to track data usage statistics for all data
            products produced by the USDA; researchers can access these
            statistics through the dashboard.
            What Is Our Goal Today? To gather
            feedback from invited participants about the current
            functionality of the USDA dashboard and potential future
            improvements.
            How Will We Get There? Attendees of this
            workshop will participate in guided focus groups and
            facilitated discussions, providing inputs that will
            contribute to shaping the development of the tool. We will
            gather your feedback about the current functionality of the
            dashboard and suggestions on potential future
            improvements.

articles.title: Additional Resources
articles.contents:
Discovering Data Use and Value for Research and Policy
Special Issue
This workshop is particularly timely as the Harvard Data Science Review has recently published a special issue, “Democratizing Data: Discovering Data Use for Research and Policy,” presenting cutting-edge ideas on using robust AI tools to support evidence building in public policy and science.




Webinar
An accompanying Webinar (May 21-22, 2024) will feature authors of the papers, providing practical insights and a vision for how bottom-up collaborations and communities of practice can help shape the future of data democratization.

articles.title: How Can the Dashboard Help You with Your Research?
articles.contents:
Activity: Using the Dashboard
Time: 15 minutes
Objective: You will use the dashboard to find information about the dataset assigned to your breakout group (see table below). You will be asked a series of questions that are aimed to find specific data usage statistics for your assigned dataset.
Breakout Group
Assigned Dataset
Group 1
Census of Agriculture
Group 2
FoodAPS
Group 3
Current Population Survey – Food Security Supplement
Group 4
Food Access Research Atlas
Tasks
UPDATE SCENARIOS TO MATCH THE FUNCTIONALITY OF THE SITE
USE CONSISTENT PHRASING TO HAVE THEM ANSWER QUESTIONS WHERE WE KNOW THE RIGHT ANSWERS
HAVE THEM FIND THE “RIGHT ANSWER”
As you navigate the dashboard to answer the questions below, please make use of the chat feature in Zoom to provide comments, in real time, about your experience. Our note takers will be collecting your feedback.
Locate your assigned dataset: Given the USDA-produced dataset have you been assigned, navigate to the location on the page where you can filter through the list of datasets.
Example dataset: Farm to School Census
Identify an expert: Who can we ask for help?
Answer: Becca Jablonski
Identify five papers we can read: What papers can we read?
Answer: Big Hunger
Where is a good place to do a literature review?
Answer: Journal of Hunger and Environmental Nutrition
Where might publish?
Answer:
But, what if I want to target an Ag Econ journal?
Answer: Go to “All Science Journal Classification Subfields”, Select “Economics and Econometrics”
If time allows, clear your filter and pick a new dataset.
Reflection Questions
(8 minutes)
After you have gone through the dashboard and answered the questions, we will reconvene as a group to answer the following reflection questions.
What features of the dashboard did you find particularly useful or surprising?
What limitations or problems did you encounter while navigating the dashboard?
What features would you add to the dashboard?
Thank you for sharing


Go to Large Group Share

articles.title: Large Group Share
articles.contents:
Reflection Questions
Time: 12 minutes Led by: Alessandro Bonanno
Each note taker, please summarize themes from your group’s discussion.
What features of the dashboard did you find particularly useful or surprising? (Group 1 starts)
What limitations or problems did you encounter while navigating the dashboard? (Group 2 starts)
What features would you add to the dashboard? (Group 3 starts)
Final Question
Time: 8 minutes Led by: Lauren Chenarides
For the remainder of our time, we invite all participants to share their answers to the following question. Please use the “Raise Hand” feature in Zoom or write your comment in the chat.
Would you use this tool in your own research? Why or why not? (Open discussion)

Go to Concluding Remarks

articles.title: Welcome to Democratizing Data
articles.contents:
Contents
Thank You for Joining Us!
Acknowledgement
A Special Welcome from Julia Lane and Joe Parsons
Why Your Participation Matters

Workshop Details
Team Introductions
Workshop Etiquette
Breakout Groups


Thank You for Joining Us!
Time: 2 minutes Led by: Lauren Chenarides
We are delighted to have you participate in this workshop, aimed at exploring a prototype dashboard to track data usage statistics for USDA datasets. The USDA and their partners are developing a dashboard to track who and how USDA-produced datasets are used by the public, an initiative inspired by the Foundations for Evidence-Based Policymaking Act of 2018. The purpose of this workshop is to collect feedback from prospective users of the dashboard, and to use these comments to refine and improve the dashboard to better serve the needs of the research community.
Acknowledgement
This workshop is supported by the USDA Economic Research Service (ERS) and the National Agricultural Statistical Service (NASS). We would like to thank the following individuals:
Julia Lane (New York University)
Nancy Potok (Former Chief Statistician of the United States)
Spiro Stefanou (USDA ERS)
Kelly Maguire (USDA ERS)
Joe Parsons (USDA NASS)
Hubert Hamer (USDA NASS)
Nick Pallotta (USDA NASS)
Tina Zdawczyk (Elsevier)
We welcome them to the workshop!
A Special Welcome from Julia Lane and Joe Parsons
Time: 3 minutes 

Julia Lane           Joe Parsons    
Why Your Participation Matters
Research Value: Your engagement is central to the development process. As a research-oriented agricultural economist, your insights and feedback will directly influence the development of this platform, ensuring it aligns with the actual needs of the community. Your contributions today will inform the platform’s future enhancements, making it more intuitive and valuable for researchers like you.
Networking and Knowledge Sharing Value: This workshop is designed to be interactive and discussion-based, bringing together research-active agricultural economists. It represents a unique opportunity to connect, share knowledge, and learn from your peers—some of whom you may already know and others you are yet to meet. We hope these interactions foster a sense of community and collaboration.
Community Impact: The exclusivity of this workshop, limited to 40 agricultural economists, highlights the curated nature of this event. Your nomination to participate is a testament to the value we believe you bring to these discussions. Together, we have the potential to shape a tool that will serve not just our immediate needs but also set a benchmark for data discovery and application in policy oriented research.
Workshop Details
Team Introductions
Time: 3 minutes Led by: Allie Bauman
The workshop is being led by a team from Colorado State University:


Allie Bauman


Brooke Fitzgerald


Rebecca Cleary


Taís de Menezes


Alessandro Bonanno


Mackenzie Gill


Lauren Chenarides


Sione Ikeme


Mayla Boguslav


Workshop Etiquette
Time: 1 minute Led by: Rebecca Cleary
To ensure a smooth and productive workshop experience for everyone, please follow these Zoom etiquette guidelines:
Keep video on when possible (particularly in the breakout rooms). Keeping your video on helps maintain engagement and create a more interactive environment.
Use the “Raise Hand” feature to ask questions or make comments. The discussant will call on you when it’s your turn.
Be on mute unless you’re speaking. This helps reduce background noise and ensure that the speaker is heard clearly.
Please respect the contributions of others and avoid interrupting when someone else is speaking.
If you have questions or need further explanation, please use the chat feature to ask for clarification.
Breakout Groups
Time: 1 minute Led by: Rebecca Cleary
The majority of the workshop will be spent in breakout groups. You will be assigned to one of four breakout groups. Assignments are based on your research area or sub-discipline specialty. Participants will take part in two activities within their breakout rooms. All participants will reconvene to share their experience toward the end of the workshop. The workshop moderator will keep track of time and inform breakout groups how much time remains within the breakout rooms.
Each breakout group will have a discussant and a note taker, assigned below:
Breakout Group
Discussant
Note Taker
Group 1
Allie Bauman
Brooke Fitzgerald
Group 2
Becky Cleary
Taís de Menezes
Group 3
Alessandro Bonanno
Mackenzie Gill
Group 4
Lauren Chenarides
Sione Ikeme
Moderator
Mayla Boguslav

We value your perspective in shaping the development of this tool. We look forward to your active participation, insightful discussions, and feedback during this workshop.
Please hang tight, as you will now be moved into to your breakout rooms.






Go to Breakout Group Activities
